title: When someone makes a cover of a song, do they get hit with a copyright strike? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. But. Yes, recording a cover of someone else's song violates the author's Right To Perform. The bigger question is: How does that play out, practically? These days, YouTube's algorithm for scouring it content for copyright violations is pretty good. They'll catch it. However, the vast majority of musicians don't actually NOT want you to play their music. They just want to get paid for it. YouTube monetizes your views by selling ads which wind up in your YouTube video. A percentage of those proceeds go back to the recording artist. Sometimes, the algorithm doesn't catch bedroom guitar players and…you get away with it. The alternative would be for YouTube to purge a LOT of content or for the copyright owner to sue. Neither of those are great options and nobody really makes money that way. Yes, unauthorized covers are not legal. But, YouTube found a way to get 1) Artists justly paid and 2) Your video to stay online.

By “get hit with copyright,” I think you mean “infringe on the copyrights of others”. Yes, they do. That’s why people that make covers of songs secure the appropriate license to do so. There are a number of agencies through which you can go to secure the rights to record and distribute a song cover. The cost is typically less than $100 and can be as cheap as $20 or so. Once a license is secured, that person would no longer infringing on copyright (because they licensed the rights).

If the cover artist gets permission from the copyright hold there’s no problem because they have a ‘license’ to use the copyrighted material. However if they do it without permission they can be sued. ‘Fair Use’ is often cited as permission but it’s not as applicable as many think.

There are deals with big copyright clearing houses (in the USA, mostly ASCAP and BMI) that are in the business of making sure everybody’s royalties get paid. There is in fact the concept of a “compulsory license” by which the copyright holder is obliged to give permission (in return for royalties) unless the cover version does harm in some way to the song or to its owner.
Yes, they do. And if that new version makes enough noise with people, you can bet the new creator will be receiving a letter from the copyright owner’s publisher or attorney.

A short answer without discussing all the legal aspects of this is no, it is not copy infringement. As long as you comply with the performance rights licensing and fees you can cover all the songs you desire. You will have to pay royalties on sales and performances.

For use in a video? Almost always. It is cheap and easy to buy a mechanical license that allows you to record an audio cover. You can then put that on SoundCloud or Bandcamp. But use in YouTube or Facebook? Videos need a different license and you have to negotiate that the same way movies and TV do. And this is quite expensive. So pick the right platform.

Why someone makes a cover of a song without permission of the song’s copyright owner, they are infringing on the owner’s copyright. If that person posts that cover on YouTube or some other sharing platform, then the platform may give the person a copyright strike, and if the owner receives to many copyright strikes, the platform may suspend the person’s account.
Authorship is everywhere. Each creative work is protected. All records, like all movies should have a generic. Using this paradigm, musician may fix the value gap and regain their authentic rights.

Generally NOT on YouTube who has licenses with 95% of the publishers. Yeah, an occasional clunker will get you into trouble. Can’t help that. Everywhere else? Definately you’ll get into trouble without your own Sync license.

The Complete Guide To Fair Use & YouTube “Performing Copyrighted Music On YouTube. There are a lot of YouTubers who play covers of original songs. Whether or not this is covered under fair use is tricky. Obviously, you will be putting your own spin on the song but whether this is transformative enough to make it fair use is sort of a grey area”
